name.text: 35.2.1.2 Sample space of a single coin toss

questiontext.text:
If the sample space can be written in the form of a list (possibly infinite) then it is called a discrete sample space (e.g. number of tosses of a fair coin before Heads occurs). If this is not possible then it is called a continuous sample space (e.g. positions where shells land in a tank battle). The following example, therefore, concerns a discrete sample space.

Example

Obtain the sample space of the experiment throwing a single coin.

Solution

Consider the experiment of throwing a coin which can land Heads up \((H)\) or Tails up \((T)\). We list the outcomes as a set \(\{H, T\}\) âˆ’ the order being unimportant. This set, \(\{H, T\}\), is the sample space. On any particular throw of a coin, Heads or Tails are equally likely to occur. We say that, for a fair coin, \(H\) and \(T\) are equally likely outcomes.
